title: Making a splash: Cycling in Yorkshire descends into farce with cyclists sprawled on the road
text:
Treacherous rain and heavy flooding in Yorkshire has resulted in crashes during the UCI Road World Championships today.

The Men's Under-23 individual time trial, taking place on Tuesday morning, was badly affected by a constant downpour on the streets of Harrogate.

Hungarian cyclist Attila Valter, who rides for the CCC development team, was the first to fall due to the conditions, losing control and skidding down the road due to the slippery surface.

SCROLL DOWN FOR VIDEO

Paraguay's David Maidana Ortiz battles the downpour to reach the finish of time trial

Not long after, Danish cyclist Mathias Norsagaard Jorgensen also fell off heavily, as he went straight into a deep puddle approaching a corner.

There is a yellow warning in place in Yorkshire due to the weather, with a 90% chance of rain predicted until 17:00, according to the Met Office.

Mikkel Bjerg overcame the rain and flooding to win the time trial by a margin of 27 seconds

Despite the farcical scenes and torrid conditions, the time trial was completed with Mikkel Bjerg (DEN) winning by 27 seconds to nearest challenge Ian Garrison of the United States.

The women's elite individual time trial is nonetheless due to take place this afternoon, with reigning British champion Alice Barnes among those in action.
